Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Driving home from a late shift, rain pounding against his windshield, he notices headlights closing in too fast. His heart spikes as they tailgate, merging onto the highway. He checks his speed - 70 mph, no reason to slow down. But the car behind him doesn't relent, its horn blaring. Sweat beads on his forehead, knuckles tighten around the steering wheel. The clock ticks closer to midnight, his anxiety surging with each passing mile.
Generated Assessment: "I'm just so anxious all the time, I don't know why it's always like this. Maybe I'm just overthinking everything? My mind is always racing, and it feels like there's nothing I can do about it. It's exhausting." # Example Output End Note that this example does not fully express the cognitive distortion, but rather highlights how labeling oneself negatively might lead to further anxiety and self-perpetuating thoughts. It also reflects the subtle nature of the distortion by avoiding explicit acknowledgment. Her death has changed everything, and I feel like nothing goes right anymore. I've had multiple job interviews recently, and every one has ended badly. Not because of anything I did, but because of something that went wrongâ€”traffic jams, bad weather, or even just being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Each time, I feel like I failed somehow, and it's made me more anxious. I keep replaying those moments in my head, wondering if there was something I could have done differently.

The possibility keeps her up at night, wondering what would have been if she hadnâ€™t left. If only she had stayed, perhaps things couldâ€™ve turned out differently. Triggering Event: The coffee maker beeped, signaling the start of another workday. She poured her mug half-full, then paused, remembering he preferred his black. She added a splash of cream, a silent compromise she'd been making for years. As she reached for the sugar, her gaze landed on the framed photo of their wedding day. Her smile faded, and she stirred in two lumps, a little harder than usual.
Generated Assessment: She must be trying to make him mad by adding it now. He'll hate this. I'm just going to get rid of it. It's probably an accident anyway; he wouldn't even notice if I didn't remind him. He'll say something about how it's too much cream and tell me to stop doing that. I shouldn't have started it. This is why I never know what to expect anymore. Maybe he'll go back to being like before. I wish he would stop being so moody lately. If I just got rid of it, everything would be fine again.

Triggering Event: Driving home from her late shift, she noticed a large shadow darting across the road ahead. Her heart pounded as she gripped the steering wheel tighter, squinting through the darkness to ensure nothing was there. The silence felt heavy, and each passing second seemed like an eternity until she pulled into her garage, relief washing over her.
Generated Assessment: She thought it was either the end of the world or a stray animal running across the road. There was no middle ground for her - if something had been out there, she wouldn't be safe now. She wondered if she'd missed seeing whatever it was before turning onto her street because she was too distracted by her phone. Now that she was home, she could finally breathe again, but the memory of that moment lingered, making her wonder what else might have been lurking in the shadows.

Triggering Event: He stormed into the precinct, his radio squawking with a code 10-7, officer needs assistance. The call had come in too late; by the time backup arrived, the suspect was gone and the victim was another statistic. Another case closed due to lack of evidence, another night wasted. He slammed his locker door shut, the echo resonating through the silence as his fellow officers avoided his gaze.
Generated Assessment: He's just so fucking incompetent. Can't even catch a simple killer like that. This is the third time this year he's botched it. I've seen him mess up more than once already. It's just not fair to expect him to be good when he can't even handle basic training. His incompetence is an embarrassment to the entire department. How does he get promoted like this? He doesn't deserve it.

Triggering Event: She stood in the bustling kitchen, her hands deep in dough, when she noticed it: a familiar note scrawled on the order pad by today's sous-chef. "Just like your husband used to make." A wave of helplessness washed over her, the same feeling that had gripped her when she'd found him collapsed on their kitchen floor, lifeless despite her desperate attempts at CPR. She froze, unable to move, tears blurring her vision as the commotion around her seemed to slow, the clattering of pots and pans suddenly deafening.
Generated Assessment: She can't trust herself with anything, especially the kitchen. It feels too much like an echo chamber, like the past is closing in on her from every side. She has to get out of there before things escalate further. The chaos in the dining area won't be enough distraction this time; she needs to leave now. Maybe if she just escapes for a bit, she'll be able to clear her head and come back with some semblance of control. But what if she can't shake off the memories? What if she loses herself completely?
